user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_init_one_time:
```c
_MHD_static_inline bool
digest_init_one_time (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
                      enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo algo)
{
#ifdef _DEBUG
  da->uninitialised = false;
  da->algo_selected = false;
  da->ready_for_hashing = false;
  da->hashing = false;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == algo)
  {
    da->algo = MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5;
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->algo_selected = true;
#endif
    MHD_MD5_init_one_time (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
    return true;
  }
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == algo)
  {
    da->algo = MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256;
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->algo_selected = true;
#endif
    MHD_SHA256_init_one_time (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
    return true;
  }
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == algo)
  {
    da->algo = MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256;
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->algo_selected = true;
#endif
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
    return true;
  }
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */

  da->algo = MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_INVALID;
  return false; /* Unsupported or bad algorithm */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided function body. There are no tokens such as __attribute__, __asm, __inline__ (compiler keyword forms), __declspec, __forceinline, register storage-class extensions, or other compiler-specific keywords that are explicitly documented as language extensions.

Notes for investigators (not flagged as suspicious fragments here because they are not explicit extensions in this snippet):
- The identifier _MHD_static_inline appears before the return type; in this file it is a macro name. Its use in itself is not a language extension. If that macro expands to a compiler-specific extension (for example __inline__, __forceinline, __attribute__((...)), __declspec(...) or other non-standard constructs), then the macro definition must be inspected to determine whether an actual language extension is used. If the macro expands to standard C (e.g., "static inline"), then it is compliant with Rule 1.2.
- The use of bool/true/false is from standard C (stdbool.h in C99); it is not a compiler extension.
- Preprocessor conditionals (_DEBUG, MHD_MD5_SUPPORT, etc.) and function calls/macros like MHD_MD5_init_one_time are not compiler language extensions themselves; their definitions would need to be checked only if they contain compiler-specific constructs.

Given only this code fragment, there are no explicit language extensions to report under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2. If you want definitive verification, provide the macro definitions (particularly _MHD_static_inline and any MHD_* macros) and any compiler flags or documentation that indicate compiler-specific extensions are being used.
